description.summary: Slavic and Germanic nightmare spirit, the female counterpart to the Alp. The etymological root of the English word 'nightmare,' representing a female entity that sits on sleepers' chests, causing nightmares and paralysis.
description.full: The Mara is a female nightmare spirit from Slavic and Germanic folklore, representing the etymological origin of the English word 'nightmare' (literally 'night-Mara'). Described as a female entity that visits sleepers at night, the Mara sits on the victim's chest like riding a horse, causing bad dreams, sleep paralysis, and suffocating sensations. In Slavic traditions, the Mara has a dual nature—sometimes appearing as a demonic entity, other times as the involuntarily wandering soul of a living person (often a woman) who leaves her body at night. These individuals might be identified by disheveled hair and sweating after their nocturnal activities. Protection methods include iron objects, brooms by the door, shoes placed backwards, and Christian prayers. The Mara represents one of the most widespread cultural interpretations of sleep paralysis, with the word itself surviving in modern English long after the original supernatural meaning faded.

etymology.origin: From Proto-Germanic *marōn, from Proto-Indo-European *mor- (to rub away, harm)

related_phenomena.name: Succubus
related_phenomena.description: Female demon that oppresses male sleepers

appearance.description: Female spirit or soul, often invisible
In Slavic tradition, may be soul of living woman
Disheveled or wild hair (in physical hosts)
Feels heavy when sitting on chest

physical.dual_nature: Can be either a demonic entity or the involuntarily wandering soul of a living person
physical.morphology: Primarily spiritual/incorporeal, though associated with physical changes in human hosts

abilities.description: Rides sleepers like horses, causing nightmares
Sits on chest causing paralysis and suffocation sensation
In Slavic tradition, soul leaves body at night

behavior.attack_pattern: Visits sleepers at night, particularly targeting those who sleep on their backs

slavic_tradition.dual_nature: The Mara can be a separate demonic entity OR the wandering soul of a living person

involuntary_mara.description: Some people become Maras involuntarily, their souls leaving their bodies at night
identification: Born with caul or under certain conditions
involuntary_mara.control: The person may have no conscious awareness or control of their night activities

slavic_tradition.victim_mara_relationship: Both the Mara (if human) and the victim suffer from the phenomenon

preventive_measures.description: Mara must count broom straws before entering
Place shoes with toes pointing away from bed

against_human_mara.description: If a living person is suspected of being Mara, securing their body prevents soul from wandering

range.description: Slavic and Germanic cultural regions across Central and Eastern Europe

origins.cultural_roots: Ancient Slavic and Germanic folk traditions
origins.folklore_connections: Part of broader Indo-European nightmare spirit traditions

history.linguistic_importance: The word 'Mara' survived into modern English as 'mare' in 'nightmare,' preserving ancient folklore in contemporary language even after the original meaning was largely forgotten

scientific_explanation.interpretation: The Mara represents a cultural explanation for sleep paralysis. The sensation of chest pressure, inability to move, and sense of presence during sleep-wake transitions were interpreted as a spirit 'riding' the sleeper.
scientific_explanation.sleep_paralysis: Physiologically identical to sleep paralysis experiences worldwide, culturally interpreted through Slavic/Germanic folklore

folklore.role: Served as explanation for sleep paralysis and nightmares across multiple cultures
folklore.cultural_sensitivity: Slavic and Germanic folk tradition, important linguistic heritage

linguistic_legacy.significance: One of the most successful folklore terms to survive in modern language
linguistic_legacy.modern_usage: English speakers use 'nightmare' daily without awareness of the Mara spirit origin

sources.title: The Terror That Comes in the Night
